translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Hairy Needle
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā gayāyaṁ viharati ṭaṅkitamañce sūcilomassa yakkhassa bhavane.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā gayā ayam viharati ṭaṅkita mañce sūcilomassa yakkhassa bhavane
translated: At one time the Blessed One was staying at Gayā on the Hairy Needle’s peak, in the dwelling of the spirit Hairy Needle.

original: Tena kho pana samayena kharo ca yakkho sūcilomo ca yakkho bhagavato avidūre atikkamanti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena kharaḥ ca yakkhaḥ sūcilomaḥ ca yakkhaḥ bhagavataḥ avidūre atikkamanti
translated: Now on that occasion the spirits Rough and Hairy Needle were passing not far from the Blessed One.

original: Atha kho kharo yakkho sūcilomaṁ yakkhaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho kharaḥ yakkhaḥ sūcilomam yakkham etat avoca
translated: Then the spirit Rough said to the spirit Hairy Needle,
“That’s the contemplative.”
“That’s not the contemplative. That’s the contemplative’s apprentice.

original: Yāvāhaṁ jānāmi yadi vā so samaṇo, yadi vā so samaṇako”ti.
analyzed: yāvā aham jānāmi yadi vā saḥ samaṇaḥ yadi vā saḥ samaṇakaḥ iti
translated: I’ll find out whether he’s the contemplative or the contemplative’s apprentice.”

original: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato kāyaṁ upanāmesi.
analyzed: atha kho sūcilomaḥ yakkhaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavataḥ kāyam upanāmesi
translated: Then the spirit Hairy Needle went to the Blessed One and touched the Blessed One’s body.
Then the Blessed One withdrew his body.

original: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho sūcilomaḥ yakkhaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the spirit Hairy Needle said to the Blessed One,
“Are you afraid of me, contemplative?”

analyzed: na khvā aham te āvusaḥ bhāyāmi
translated: “I’m not afraid of you, friend.

analyzed: api ca te samphassaḥ pāpakaḥ ti
translated: But your touch is evil.”
“I’ll ask you a question, contemplative.

original: Sace me na byākarissasi, cittaṁ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṁ vā te phālessāmi, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmī”ti.🔽“Na khvāhaṁ taṁ, āvuso, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā🔽pajāya sadevamanussāya yo me cittaṁ vā khipeyya hadayaṁ vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā
analyzed: sace me na byākarissasi cittam vā te khipissāmi hadayam vā te phālessāmi pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmi iti  na khvā aham te āvuso passāmi sa devake loke sa mārake sa brahmake sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇiyā  pajāya sa deva manussāya yaḥ me cittam vā khipeyya hadayam vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā
translated: If you don’t answer me, I’ll either crush your heart, or pluck out your heart, or seize you by the feet and hurl you to the other side of the Ganges.”

“I don’t see anyone in the cosmos with its gods, lords of death, & Brahmas, in this generation with its contemplatives & brahmans, its royalty & common people, who could crush my heart, or pluck out my heart, or seize me by the feet and hurl me to the other side of the Ganges.

original: Api ca tvaṁ, āvuso, puccha yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
analyzed: api ca tvai āvuso puccha yat ākaṅkhasi iti
translated: But ask me whatever you want.”

original: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:🔽“Rāgo ca doso ca kutonidānā,
analyzed: atha kho sūcilomaḥ yakkhaḥ bhagavantam gāthāya ajjhabhāsi  rāgaḥ ca dosaḥ ca kutonidānā
translated: Then the spirit Needle-Hair addressed the Blessed One with this verse:🔽“Where do passion & aversion come from?
Where do discontent, delight, & goosebumps come from?
Where do thoughts & ideas come from?

original: Kumārakā dhaṅkamivossajanti”.🔽“Rāgo ca doso ca itonidānā,
analyzed: kumārakāḥ dhaṅkam iva ussajanti  rāgaḥ ca dosaḥ ca itas nidānā
translated: They fall on a person like a swarm of bees.”🔽“Passion & aversion come from here.

analyzed: aratī ratī loma hasaḥ ita ojā
translated: Discontent, delight, & goosebumps come from here.
Thoughts & ideas come from here.
They fall on a person like a swarm of bees.
Born of affection, self-produced,
like the branches of a banyan tree.
Many are the beings who are attached to sensual pleasures,
Like creepers spread in the forest.
Those who understand the source of that,
They remove it, listen, spirit!
They cross this hard-to-cross flood,
Not crossed before, for the non-arising of renewed existence.”
The Thread on the Needle-Hairs is the fifth.
